contenido.en:
The doctrine of the Trinity teaches that God is one being in three persons: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. However, the Bible does not teach this idea nor does it mention the word 'Trinity'. Instead, the Scriptures present Jehovah as the only true God, Jesus as His subordinate Son, and the holy spirit as God's active force. This doctrine was adopted centuries after Christ and is not based on the teachings of Jesus or his apostles.

üîπ The Bible Teaches That Jehovah Is One
> ‚ÄúJehovah our God is one Jehovah.‚Äù ‚Äî Deuteronomy 6:4
God is never presented as a 'three-in-one' being but as a single, supreme person.

üîπ Jesus Is Inferior to God, Not Equal
> ‚ÄúThe Father is greater than I am.‚Äù ‚Äî John 14:28

The Bible portrays the holy spirit as God's power or active force, not as a person.

üîπ There Is No Biblical Basis for a Trinity
> ‚ÄúThere is actually to us one God, the Father... and one Lord, Jesus Christ.‚Äù ‚Äî 1 Corinthians 8:6
The apostle Paul made a clear distinction between God and Jesus without mentioning a third person.

üîπ The Doctrine Was Influenced by Pagan Philosophy
> The Trinity was formally defined at the Council of Nicaea in 325 CE, shaped by Greco-Roman ideas.
This concept did not originate in the Bible but centuries later, as acknowledged by many historians.
